content.description: Start up a blank wall past a few knobs, then up past a detached flake feature about the size of a flattened climbing pack. Thankfully it is 100% bolt protected because a cam under this flake would probably pop it off in a fall. This climb is fairly sustained, as compared to some of the others that let up in the first few bolts. Continue up fun climbing to the Mussy Hooks, a little to the left as you reach lower angle rock. This anchor is shared with The Rubicon Trail. Note: 70M rope only.
content.location: It is probably easiest to first find The Rubicon Trail which is just downstream of two large boulders, and this is the climb to the right.

content.description: Climb the easier ground between the bolted routes straight up to the shared anchor.
content.location:
Top rope directly below the shared anchor of The Rubicon Trail and

Slick Slice of Slab.

content.description: You can start from the ground or you can step across from the boulder for an easier start closer to the bolt. The slope eases midway which is why there are few bolts up high. There are clippable Mussy hooks at the top to lower off of.
content.protection: Bolts with sport anchors at the top.
content.location: This starts between a large boulder and the large bushy area as you walk up the granite gully.

content.description:
Named after the famous 4x4 trail that starts at the end of Ice House Road at Loon Lake and runs overland 22 miles to Lake Tahoe.

Fun climbing through a dike and straight up the slab. The start to and above the first bolt is the crux - a spot is helpful until the first bolt is reached.  The difficulty lets up quite a bit as the rock becomes more featured and less steep.  The anchors (Mussy Hooks) are a little to the right as you near the end just above some large horizontal dikes. The anchor is shared with Slick Slice of Slab.
content.location: Look for the area of large bushes at the bottom of the sport climbs with two large boulders below the bushes.  This climb starts just below the lowest boulder.

content.description: Niko Nakamura saw some bolts high up and thought they were a rebolted runout route, but they were old lonely loose bolts which led to a scary downclimb by Niko. The bolts were fixed, more added, along with a sport anchor at the top. Its now a nice straight forward, fun sport climb up the slab.
content.location: This is the leftmost of three sport climbs that share an anchor that lies under a shallow roof.

content.description: Just plain fun.  Most right of three climbs off the same top anchor under a shallow roof.
content.location: Start at lowest point around.  Go up.  Second bolt is kind of high but easy to get there. The pitch heads straight up, but veers a little left after the fourth bolt and after the fifth bolt head left to the anchor.

content.description: A fun easy sport route up a fine slab of granite.
content.protection: 5 bolts.  A little runout at the top but its very easy up there.
content.location: This the climb with the bolt right off the boulder.  You can just about reach over and clip it.  The climb starts from the ground to the right.  So your choice - you can start from the ground, you can preclip the bolt and start from the ground, or you can totally cheat and step across from the boulder.
